newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico stocks advance to new record close.
newsitem.headline: Mexico stocks advance to new record close.

text.p: Mexican stocks ended up at their fourth record close in a row on Monday.

Dealers and analysts said stockpickers stepped in to buy after an earlier bout of moderate profit-taking had made prices cheaper. "The market still looks strong. I honestly expected more profit-taking, but the bourse absorbed selling very well when buyers took advantage of lower prices," said a stock promoter who asked not to be named.
Final closing prices situated the blue chip IPC share index .MXX up 15.21 points on the day, or 0.36 percent, at a new record close of 4,259.84.
"Several stocks are well priced and fundamentally sound," the promoter added.
Dealers stressed the market was quiet, and moderate buying had an exaggerated effect amid thin volume.
"The market got a second wind. Earlier selling was not heavy, and dealing was quiet," one floor trader said.
Trading volume .TV.MX was restrained at just 85.5 million shares traded, and dealers noted one hefty cross trade accounted for more than 10 percent of that total.
"The market was dull. There was no overall trend, apart from financials, which were strong," a desk trader said.
"Financials are still cheap. They've had a terrible time over the last two years," a floor trader said. "They could finally be waking up."

Bancomer, one of Mexico's biggest financial groups, was the most heavily traded gainer. Its B shares ended up 10 centavos to 3.80 peso, while the A shares gained 8 centavos to 2.05 pesos. The two share classes accounted for 22 percent of all shares traded.
Dealers also drew attention to retail chain Comerci, which climbed 48 centavos to 6.86 pesos at brisk trade to head the prominent gainers' list.
"Comerci had lagged far behind recent market gains," a floor trader said.
Traders said some stocks, notably tortilla and corn flour firm Maseca, had not recovered from earlier profit-taking. Maseca shed 6 centavos to end at 8.08 pesos.
On the broad market, 106 stocks changed hands in total, of which gainers narrowly outpaced sliders by 45 to 42.
